newsitem.title: BELGIUM: EU, Britain discuss "quota hopping" fishermen.
newsitem.headline: EU, Britain discuss "quota hopping" fishermen.

text.p: The European Commission and Britain were starting talks on Tuesday to tighten rules on "quota hopping" fishing vessels, British Agriculture and Fisheries Minister Jack Cunningham said on Tuesday.
"Quota hopping is at the top of our agenda," Cunningham told a news briefing after a getting-to-know-you meeting with EU Fisheries Commissioner Emma Bonino.
"We agreed that our officials and Bonino's officials will start talks this afternoon to seek agreement on a common way forward," he added.
Quota hopping is the practice whereby foreign fishermen have legally set up flag of convenience operations in Britain and bought licences giving them a share of the British fish quota.
Some 150 foreign vessels, mainly Spanish and Dutch owned, now take over one quarter of the British quota.
Cunningham said the new British Labour government would like if possible to see a protocal agreed on "quota hoppers" at the inter-governmental conference in Amsterdam in June.
The former Conservative gopvernment had threatened to block a review of the EU treaty by the conference unless the 15-nation bloc changed its fishing policies.
British Fisheries Minister Elliot Morley said British registered vessels should have a close connection with Britain.
"There ought to be a strong link between the member state and the operation of those vessels," he said, adding that he was encouraged by Bonino's "very positive" response.
Currently "quota hopper" vessels ccould operate without coming near British ports, he said, adding, "That's what we want to tighten up on."
Cunningham said the government accepted proposals for fishing cuts to safeguard threatened stocks but it could take some time to implement.
"If there are no fish stocks there's no fishing industry. We accept that," he said, adding that Britain was entitled to see a positive EU response to British problems.
The Conservatives had suggested that if "quota hoppers" were removed there would be virtually no need for British fishing cutbacks.
A European Commission spokesman welcomed what he described as the pragmatic approach showed by the new government.

"There are legal ways of tightening up. We have said for months that there should be an economic link between fishing licences and local fishing communities," fisheries spokesman Filippo di Robilant said.
